What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?

Comments_List: I learned how to be extremely bored in a classroom three times a week and still have the tenacity to show up. I also learned how to be talked at by a professor all class with no variation in tone or queries for student input.

I learned the conceptual background, including rationale for technological improvements over time, for NMR, ESR/EPR, MS, X-ray crystallography, microwave spectroscopy, and IR. I also feel more comfortable learning how to predict NMR spectra for first order cases and understand the advantages and disadvantages of each type of spectroscopy in addition to the theory behind them.

Knowledge:
	Detailed knowledge (development, fundamental chemistry, example spectra, math) of structural determination techniques, including NMR, ESR, X-ray, UV, Mass Spec etc.
	 of the class is NMR  this class tries to teach you NMR in excruciating detail unlike any other
	History of spectroscopic techniques and anecdotes from the era

Skills:
	How to read and draw NMR spectra in a very limited fashion
	How to understand and predict NMR coupling effects
	How to connect history and development to science

Insights:
	Techniques are constantly in transition and ever-increasingly complex

This course covers an extremely important topic in science in a terribly ineffective way. The material needs to be presented in a way that is more clear and applicable to students, instead of being told as a series of historical anecdotes that have nothing to do with the way spectroscopy is used today.
weaknesses: read from the lecture slides. strengths: easy

The class  usually considered an easy Chemistry spring elective  was quite hard this year because the midterm was unreasonably hard. The class is also incredibly boring and I could never pay attention to anything. However, the Chemistry department sets a pretty low bar (please dont major in Chemistry) so this is still a good deal.

Instructor:
	Professor Saunders is sweet, smart and hardworking. He can teach very well if you ask him one-on-one and give him a chance. He is incredibly insightful given his endless years of experience in math, science and Yale. He is a bit of a childhood genius so definitely pick his brain!
	Unfortunately, he is not the best lecturer and I was asleep in several classes / it is impossible to not be. Everyone else was on their phones/laptops or doodling on their notebooks
Assignments:
	The class had one problem set that was never checked. It was quite difficult and nothing in it was ever taught during lecture. I never did it
	There was one exam that had 3 questions. At first glance, I could do zero of the three questions even though I prepared extensively and knew his slides cold. It felt like the ultimate waste of effort and an insult to ones intelligence. The class is so random and unpredictable that it is tragic
	There is a final exam where you have an interesting conversation mostly of your choosing with Professor Saunders and he asks you about your life
	Clearly the class has incredibly low workload but it is a blackbox and can be a serious hit or miss. Would one really want an A-/B+/B in this class? Would you really want your hard work to be of zero use?
Content (lectures):
	The lecture slides are sadly a disaster. Slides are a visual medium. They cannot be just sentences and walls of text. That is pedagogy 101. I cannot believe no one in the Chemistry department has intervened. Extremely visual concepts (spectra, trends, molecules (hard names)) are all only explained in text and for me, were impossible to understand. Everything had to be Googled and the internet does not have a lot of information about things like advanced 3D NMR
	It is impossible to not fall asleep with the black and white monotony that are the slides
Do not take this course!!! It is extremely boring and nothing applicable to anyone's life is learned. Read a textbook instead.
take it if you're over chemistry as like, a concept, as i am
I would highly recommend this course. I learned a lot, and Professor Saunders made ample time for his students.
Yes it is a good chemistry class to take as an elective.
Yes I would recommend this elective to another student.
